ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I leaned about a variety of religious/non-religious belief systems and traditions that informed different ideas of a life worth living.
How to break down frameworks into digestible structures and understand similarities and differences in belief systems that seem entirely different from one another
I learned how to really engage with moral dilemmas and how to begin thinking how I want to live my life so that I leave a lasting impact.
I learned about a lot of different traditions and worldviews (Buddhism, Islam, Nietzscheism, etc.) and how to think about them in a comparative way.
Read about traditional visions of a life worth living., evaluated my own

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was overall amazing and I had a great time working with Orel and my other classmates. We had many great discussions and debates within the seminar that were conducted by Orel, and he always asked deep and specific questions that kept the class stimulating.
I think the course is incredible and the only impediment was doing it virtually, otherwise I highly recommend

I thought that the course did a great job of doing a survey of a broad series of subject matter, and also was a good balance of tasks that kept us engaged with course material while not creating busy work (ex: class presentations, class journal, and questions).
I would have preferred more seminar discussion rather than lecture-style teaching.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, Orel did a great job, but I wish it was easier to breakout into different rooms to have discussions with different groups of students.
I dont think there is much to do to really respond effectively to zoom burnout

I think that I would have really enjoyed a retreat in this course, such that we could have spent more time understanding the personal aspects of this course (trying to spend more time engaging with one another's life worth living visions and articulating specific questions that we were wrestling with in our own lives), though I know that virtual retreats are difficult.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was not bad at all. It is definitely the type of class where you get out what you put in -- but try not to think of it as a self-help class per se. Maybe it was because of Zoom, but the class discussions were usually shallow and not a lot of people did the readings. But the process of writing the essays helped me reflect on and interrogate my values and the way I live my life. Although my worldview has not changed fundamentally, I feel like my lifestyle is slightly more informed and intentional now than it was before the semester.
Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning about a series of diverse traditions or wants to spend a semester contemplating their own goals for life.

This course is hard because it is always harder to write about yourself. I think it is more challenging because no matter how hard you try to evade it, your authentic and genuine opinions will be confronted. But its not difficult to engage. This class will genuinely leave you thinking and I think it is a great opportunity to log and record where you were at during this point in your life as a twenty something year old.
Yes. I think every Yale student should take a course that encourages learning about oneself while engaging with academic application of concepts.

Yes, I would recommend this class to another student. I think that the reading materials and the asynchronous guest lecture recordings are all really rich, and I've enjoyed engaging with them. I think that the course is what you make of it, so if you aren't doing the readings or trying to engage in class discussion, it could up being a class you get less out of. On the whole though, I am glad I took it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
n/a
There were also asynchronous lectures.
